Hey folks - given the influx of newer maintainers, I'm willing to give rebasing this another shot. But it may not be for a few weeks as I'm on call at work and we're embarking on some other projects soon.

Perhaps we should reconcile it with the changes from #5083 though? I haven't looked at the code yet but I'd assume lots of conflicts.
@Eronan don't worry about #5083, it will probably be obsolete if this gets through. I will merge or close.
Only tangentially related question - does anyone on this PR know how to format an airflow env variable such that the connection is correctly populated?  cc @jjk2134
@fenglu-g sure checking now
A friendly reminder :D

Hi @bnutt - yep, I'm grappling with something simliar.
In my case, I was hoping that the amazingly ugly `AIRFLOW__KUBERNETES_ENVIRONMENT_VARIABLES__AIRFLOW__CORE__REMOTE_BASE_LOG_FOLDER` would be successful, but sadly not.

I'll let you know if I come up with anything, but I suspect it's back to configmaps.
has anyone considered implementing Okta OIDC provider, similar to google_auth.py?

> **Legend** - [Click here to learn more](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/codecov-delta)
> `Î” = absolute <relative> (impact)`, `Ã¸ = not affected`, `? = missing data`
> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/airflow/pull/5287?src=pr&el=footer). Last update [e1c1a8d...334faa9](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/airflow/pull/5287?src=pr&el=lastupdated). Read the [comment docs](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/pull-request-comments).

I still think adding docs in the same PR is necessary. I am in favour of adding documentation together with the relevant code that is modified. 

Especially in this case, this is a new way of building the DAG relationships which is the "core" of Airflow really and everyone should know how to use it. Having some PR / slack discussion describing such feature is really bad way of documenting it. Especially that this discussion was long and had many twists so it is unclear what the final intention was without reading the whole thread.

Also several other people had their strong opinions here so maybe it's good if everyone who participated will state their opinion on the current code. I don't think we all have to fully agree but maybe just one last round of comments would be great, then documentation should be added to reflect it and then we merge it. @zhongjiajie @feng-tao @Fokko @feluelle @mik-laj @XD-DENG ?
The CI failure here appears to have nothing to do with my patch ðŸ˜¢

@potiuk In this case, the patch is against v1.10.x, as I found the issue due to changes introduced in 1.10.3 - I don't believe the origin= is present on `master` when I looked, as the dags page for master is a little different. It's plausible we should also do this on master, however.

1.10.2 -> 1.10.3 has some issues with manual triggers which we're currently using while working out how our airflow is going to work, and it'd be nice if there's a 1.10.4 release to fix these - what's the plan between 1.10.x (x > 3) and 2.0.0?
@potiuk the above notwithstanding, I'm happy to listen to any further advice you have (sorry if that's not clear in my message).

Thenm if the bug has different fixes for 1.10 and 2.0 and they are significantly different, then ideally we should have two parallel PRs. We knew that the time is close when merging master -> v1.10x will become too painful and for a while I think we will have to live with this dualism in place. Most of the changes are easy to apply master-> 1.10 still.

The current general roadmap for 2.0 is being created in https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/AIRFLOW/Airflow+2.0 . Those particular issue you mention - if this is a JIRA issue and it will be solved in 2.0 we will try to backport it to 1.10.x. It's all issue-by-issue case and fairly 'distributed' so there is no central place to see what's implemented.
And BTW. the v1-10-test branch now builds fine, so you can rebase.

@potiuk I can try and come up with a PR for master - it's going to be a bit more difficult, as we don't have a 2.x-pre (master) airflow deploy anywhere to see if this works, it may be that this applies cleanly, of course ðŸ˜„ and that might be enough.

Yes I realise this potentially introduces many breaking DAGs, therefore it should be merged into Airflow 2.0 at the least.

My main reason for this change is there are so many different ways of writing Airflow code, it can be quite confusing to users (in my experience), therefore if we provide only a single possible way of providing TriggerRules and WeightRules, it should unify and improve user experience.

As an intermediate, in the BaseOperator init we could do something like this, to continue support for strings:
```python
if trigger_rule not in TriggerRule:
    try:
        # trigger rule values such as "all_done" will be converted to the TriggerRule enum
        trigger_rule = TriggerRule(trigger_rule)
        # show deprecation warning here
    except ValueError:
        # trigger_rule object is neither TriggerRule enum or string known to TriggerRule
        raise AirflowException(...)
```

What do you think?
I closed my PR, let's continue this one.

Yeah. I think that could be much more friendly. Maybe I'd rather check for the type of the value, and add Type annotation Union[TriggerRule, string] to indicate that we support both for now. 

On the other hand, the question is when such deprecation warning should turn into error - if not now with 2.0.0. So I am a bit on the fence here (though leaning towards backwards-compatibility).

Maybe others can also chime-in here with their thoughts and experience how painful it will be for the users to convert  ?

Thanks for fixing the docs. The Airflow convention is to prepend every commit message with `[AIRFLOW-...]`, `[AIRFLOW-XXX]` in the case of docs only change. Could you update your commit message?
I don't see how the CI errors and your change are related, could be a flaky test. I restarted the failed jobs.

Good point - pathlib is a higher level API. It's not necessary to use but does provide a (IMO) much clearer API.

I'm always wary of these "magic" functions such as `airflow.utils.file.mkdirs`, which seem to handle some sort of undocumented edge case. I'm not sure why they exist, because the mkdirs operation can be handled nicely with pathlib, I prefer to use native Python methods for such operations. Shall we replace it in a different PR?

This PR is missing tests.
You can refer to another PR which added new trigger rule for reference https://github.com/apache/airflow/pull/5032

Also I'm not too crazy about the name `ATLEAST_ONE_SUCCESS`.
The name should reflect the meaning. When viewing `ONE_SUCCESS `and `ATLEAST_ONE_SUCCESS `it will causes confusion between them.

As a general comment if this is merged it will open a window to many many different kinds of trigger rules. Maybe a better approach will be to design a mechanism where you can use more than one trigger rule. So for your need it will be `ALL_DONE `+ `ONE_SUCCESS`. This way there will be less new trigger rules to maintain and the functionality will grow drastically.

@ashb It's auto/forcibly update:

`Amazon Redshift provides a setting, Allow Version Upgrade, to specify whether to automatically upgrade the Amazon Redshift engine in your cluster if a new version of the engine becomes available. This setting doesn't affect the database version upgrades, which are applied during the maintenance window that you specify for your cluster. Amazon Redshift engine upgrades are major version upgrades, and Amazon Redshift database upgrades are minor version upgrades. You can disable automatic version upgrades for major versions only. For more information about maintenance windows for minor version upgrades, see Maintenance Windows. `
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/redshift/latest/mgmt/working-with-clusters.html

The 1.0 is the cluster version which the user can control if he wants to update or not. 
but the user have no control over the database version update. Redshift force update this in the maintenance windows. 
Since all users run the same cluster version (1.0)  this PR is safe to be merged in my opinion.
